metadata.titleEn: Dataset of Heihe integrated observatory network: eddy covariance system of Zhangye wetland station, 2022
metadata.description:
This dataset contains the flux measurements from the Zhangye wetland station eddy covariance system (EC) in the midstream reaches of the Heihe integrated observatory network from January 1 to December 31 in 2022. The site (100.44640° E, 38.97514° N) was located in the Zhangye City in Gansu Province. The elevation is 1460 m. The EC was installed at a height of 5.2 m, and the sampling rate was 10 Hz. The sonic anemometer faced north, and the separation distance between the sonic anemometer and the CO2/H2O gas analyzer (Gill&Li7500A) was 0.25 m.
The raw data acquired at 10 Hz were processed using the Eddypro post-processing software, including the spike detection, lag correction of H2O/CO2 relative to the vertical wind component, sonic virtual temperature correction, coordinate rotation (2-D rotation), corrections for density fluctuation (Webb-Pearman-Leuning correction), and frequency response correction. The EC data were subsequently averaged over 30 min periods. The observation data quality was divided into three classes according to the quality assessment method of stationarity (Δst) and the integral turbulent characteristics test (ITC): class 1-3 (high quality), class 4-6 (good), class 7-8 (poor, better than gap filling data), class9 (rejected). In addition to the above processing steps, the half-hourly flux data were screened in a four-step procedure: (1) data from periods of sensor malfunction were rejected; (2) data collected before or after 1 h of precipitation were rejected; (3) incomplete 30 min data were rejected when the missing data constituted more than 3% of the 30 min raw record. There were 48 records per day, and the missing data were replaced with -6999. Suspicious data were marked in red. 
The released data contained the following variables: data/time, wind direction (Wdir, °), wind speed (Wnd, m/s), the standard deviation of the lateral wind (Std_Uy, m/s), virtual temperature (Tv, ℃), H2O mass density (H2O, g/m3), CO2 mass density (CO2, mg/m3), friction velocity (ustar, m/s), stability (z/L), sensible heat flux (Hs, W/m2), latent heat flux (LE, W/m2), carbon dioxide flux (Fc, mg/ (m2s)), quality assessment of the sensible heat flux (QA_Hs), quality assessment of the latent heat flux (QA_LE), and quality assessment of the carbon flux (QA_Fc). In this dataset, the time of 0:30 corresponds to the average data for the period between 0:00 and 0:30; the data were stored in *.xls format. Detailed information can be found in the suggested references.
For more information, please refer to Liu et al. (2018) (for sites information), Liu et al. (2011) for data processing) in the Citation section.

background: Arid and semiarid regions represent approximately 30 % of the global terrestrial surface area (Dregne, 1991; Scanlon et al., 2006), and dryland expansion occurs under climate change, especially in developing countries (Huang et al., 2016). An oasis is a unique ecological landscape in arid and semi-arid areas that is not only the core of regions’ ecological environment but also the foundation of their economic development, especially in western China, which has been an important part of the “Silk Road” since ancient times. Oases comprising less than 10 % of the total area of arid regions support more than 90 % of the population in these regions of China (Chu et al., 2005; Li et al., 2016; Zhou et al., 2022). The oasis–desert system plays a crucial role in maintaining a stable ecological environment and agricultural productivity (Zhang and Zhao, 2015). Extensive studies have investigated energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas based on field and remote-sensing observations (Taha et al., 1991; Potchter et al., 2008; Xue et al., 2019; Wang et al., 2019; Zhou et al., 2022) and numerical simulations (Chu et al., 2005; Meng et al., 2009; Georgescu et al., 2011; Liu et al., 2020). In addition, oasis–desert areas located in semiarid regions have been found to be carbon sinks by previous researchers (Tagesson et al., 2016; Wang et al., 2019); thus, they can significantly affect the carbon balance of arid regions and play an increasingly important role within the global carbon cycle.
research objective: Therefore, it is critical to maintain the balance between oasis and desert systems in order to achieve the goal of sustainable oasis development. Understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is important to achieve the goals of carbon peaking and carbon neutrality in the oasis–desert area and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis. A quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases; moreover, long-term observations are indispensable.
challenges: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas are facing the crisis of ecological environment degradation, such as the drying up of rivers and lakes, the degradation of natural vegetation, the intensification of land desertification, and the frequent occurrence of dust storms, especially in many inland river basins westward along the Silk Road, such as the Tarim River basin (Zhao et al., 2013), the Aral Sea basin (Stanev et al., 2004; Crétaux et al., 2009), and the Lake Urmia basin (Stone, 2015).
methods: In this study, we present a suite of observational datasets from artificial and natural oasis–desert systems that consist of long-term energy, water vapor, carbon and methane fluxes as well as auxiliary data involving hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters from 2012 to 2021. Half-hourly turbulent flux data were acquired by an eddy covariance system and scintillometer. The hydrometeorological data (including radiation, soil heat flux, and soil temperature profiles; gradients of air temperature and humidity and of wind speed and direction; and air pressure, precipitation, and soil moisture profiles) were observed from automatic weather stations with a 10 min average period as well as the groundwater table data. Moreover, vegetation and soil parameters were also supplemented in the datasets. The data processing and quality control procedure can be divided into data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing.
dataset: The study area comprises the middle and lower reaches of the HRB, located in the arid regions of western China, that receive water from the typical cryosphere of the upper reaches. A total of 11 land surface flux and meteorological stations have been established in these regions since 2012 – 2 superstations and 9 ordinary stations. The dataset of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange observations in oasis–desert areas reported in this study (including energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes; hydrometeorological data; and vegetation and soil parameters) is freely available from the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Definition.Question: What is the 'eddy covariance method' used for data collection in environmental research?
Definition.Answer: The eddy covariance method is a data collection technique used to measure and calculate turbulent fluxes of momentum, heat, water vapor, and carbon dioxide between the surface and the atmosphere. This method involves using instruments like ultrasonic anemometers and gas analyzers, such as the CO2/H2O analyzer, to record data at high frequencies (e.g., 10Hz), which is then processed to produce average flux values over longer periods (e.g., 30 minutes) using software like Eddypro.

Definition.Question: What are 'oasis–desert interactions' and why are they significant in environmental research?
Definition.Answer: Oasis–desert interactions refer to the exchanges and balance of energy, water vapor, and carbon between oasis and desert ecosystems. These interactions are significant in environmental research as they play a critical role in maintaining ecological stability, supporting agricultural productivity, and influencing the carbon balance in arid and semi-arid regions. Understanding these interactions is crucial for achieving sustainable development, ecological security, and addressing carbon cycle dynamics in these regions.

Comparison.Question: What are the differences in the quality control procedures for data collected from the Heihe River Basin's Zhangye Wetland Station and a similar dataset from oasis–desert areas?
Comparison.Answer: The Heihe River Basin's Zhangye Wetland Station employs a quality control process that includes data filtering based on instrument errors and precipitation events, as well as checks for high missing data rates. In comparison, datasets from oasis–desert areas undergo a broader quality control process encompassing data collection, processing, and archiving, integrating diverse environmental parameters, and likely involving additional checks tailored to specific environmental conditions.

Interpretation.Question: What can be inferred about the ecological stability of oasis-desert systems based on the observed patterns in energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange data?
Interpretation.Answer: The observed patterns in energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange data could provide insights into the balance between oasis and desert systems, which is crucial for maintaining ecological stability and achieving sustainable development goals in these regions.

Interpretation.Question: How might the challenges of ecological environment degradation in arid and semiarid inland river basins influence the methodologies used for data collection in these areas?
Interpretation.Answer: The challenges such as drying rivers, vegetation degradation, and land desertification may necessitate the use of robust, long-term observational methods and advanced data processing techniques to accurately capture the environmental changes and to support effective ecological management strategies.

These factors require rigorous quality checks to ensure the accuracy and reliability of the data, especially for understanding carbon sinks and ecological interactions in arid regions.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What drives the need for long-term observational datasets in studying oasis–desert systems in arid regions?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The need for long-term observational datasets in studying oasis–desert systems is driven by the necessity to capture the temporal variability and trends in energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes. This is essential to understand the interactions between oasis and desert systems, assess the impacts of climate change, and support the sustainable management of these regions, which face ecological challenges like land degradation and water scarcity.

Such systems can help in long-term observations that are indispensable for recognizing ecological stability and supporting socioeconomic development.

Causal Consequence.Question: How does the presence of a comprehensive observational network in arid regions influence the understanding of ecological degradation challenges?
Causal Consequence.Answer: A comprehensive observational network in arid regions can significantly improve the understanding of ecological degradation challenges by providing essential data on hydrometeorology, vegetation, and soil parameters. It helps in identifying issues such as river and lake drying, vegetation degradation, and land desertification, thus aiding in the development of strategies to mitigate these challenges.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to collect long-term observational datasets in oasis–desert systems for understanding energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange?
Goal Orientation.Answer: A quantitative understanding of the energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert areas is crucial to recognize the oasis–desert interactions and is significant to protect the ecological stability and socioeconomic development of oases; moreover, long-term observations are indispensable.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it critical to maintain a balance between oasis and desert systems when utilizing datasets for sustainable oasis development?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Maintaining the balance between oasis and desert systems is critical to achieve the goal of sustainable oasis development and support the ecological security and sustainable development of the oasis, which involves understanding the basic characteristics of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in these ecosystems.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What are the key procedural steps involved in processing raw data from an eddy covariance system to ensure high-quality flux measurements in arid and semiarid regions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The key procedural steps in processing raw data from an eddy covariance system include outlier removal, delay time correction, coordinate rotation (two-step coordinate rotation), frequency response correction, ultrasonic virtual temperature correction, and density (WPL) correction. Additionally, quality evaluation of flux values is performed based on atmospheric stability and turbulence similarity characteristics, with further screening of flux values by removing data from faulty instruments and periods of precipitation.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can long-term observational datasets be effectively compiled and shared, incorporating diverse data types such as energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes, alongside hydrometeorological and vegetation parameters?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Long-term observational datasets can be effectively compiled and shared by establishing a comprehensive data collection process involving an array of land surface flux and meteorological stations. These datasets should include energy, water vapor, and carbon fluxes, as well as auxiliary hydrometeorological, vegetation, and soil parameters. Data processing should involve systematic collection, processing, and archiving procedures, followed by making the data freely available from a central data center, such as the National Tibetan Plateau Data Center.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What instrumentation and data management practices are necessary to accurately measure and manage hydrometeorological data, including soil heat flux, temperature profiles, and precipitation in oasis–desert systems?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Accurate measurement and management of hydrometeorological data require the use of automatic weather stations equipped with instruments for observing radiation, soil heat flux, soil temperature profiles, gradients of air temperature and humidity, wind speed and direction, air pressure, and precipitation. These stations should collect data with a 10-minute average period and include groundwater table measurements. Effective data management practices involve structured data processing, quality control, and routine archiving.

Enablement.Question: How do data processing techniques, such as coordinate rotation and frequency response corrections, enable the refinement of flux measurements collected in oasis-desert systems?
Enablement.Answer: Data processing techniques, including coordinate rotation and frequency response corrections, are crucial for refining flux measurements by aligning wind components and correcting for sensor response times, respectively. These techniques ensure that the data reflects accurate physical processes occurring in oasis-desert systems, aiding in the understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchanges.

Enablement.Question: In what ways do automatic weather stations contribute to the enablement of continuous hydrometeorological data collection in challenging environments like the Heihe River Basin?
Enablement.Answer: Automatic weather stations facilitate continuous hydrometeorological data collection by providing consistent measurements of variables such as radiation, soil heat flux, air temperature, humidity, and wind speed. These stations operate with a high temporal resolution, such as 10-minute averages, enabling comprehensive monitoring of environmental conditions in challenging areas like the Heihe River Basin.

Expectation.Question: Why might it be challenging to maintain long-term observational datasets in arid and semiarid inland river basins?
Expectation.Answer: Inland river basins in arid and semiarid areas face environmental degradation challenges such as drying rivers, vegetation degradation, desertification, and dust storms, particularly in regions along the Silk Road. These challenges can complicate the maintenance of long-term observational datasets.

Expectation.Question: What are the expected benefits of understanding energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems?
Expectation.Answer: A quantitative understanding of energy, water vapor, and carbon exchange in oasis–desert ecosystems is essential for achieving carbon peaking and carbon neutrality goals, supporting ecological security, and ensuring sustainable development of oases. It also aids in recognizing oasis–desert interactions and protects ecological stability and socioeconomic development.

Judgmental.Answer: The data processing methods, including Eddypro software for 30-minute data processing and quality evaluations such as atmospheric stability and turbulence characteristics, are effective for ensuring the reliability of large-scale datasets. These steps, along with quality assessments of flux values, contribute to the robustness of the data collected in oasis–desert ecosystems.

Judgmental.Question: In what ways could current data collection approaches be improved to better capture the dynamics of oasis–desert systems?
Judgmental.Answer: Improvements could include increasing the spatial and temporal resolution of data collection, incorporating additional parameters like methane fluxes, and enhancing the integration of remote sensing data with ground-based observations. These enhancements would provide a more detailed understanding of the complex interactions within oasis–desert systems.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore the methodologies used in data processing and quality control for hydrometeorological and flux data in arid and semiarid regions.
Request/Directive.Answer: Data processing and quality control involve several steps such as data collection, data processing, and data archiving and sharing. The processing of flux data includes steps like despiking, time delay correction, coordinate rotation, frequency response correction, sonic temperature correction, and WPL correction. Quality evaluation of flux values focuses on testing atmospheric stationarity and turbulence similarity characteristics.
